title: 107_s1265
content: The "Children's Adjustment, Relief, and Education Act" or the "CARE Act" defines a "secondary school student" as a student in grades 7 through 12. It repeals a section of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 regarding in-state tuition for college-age alien children and addresses cancellation of removal and adjustment of status for certain alien children. The CARE Act amends Section 240A of the Immigration and Nationality Act to provide a special rule for residents brought to the United States as children. The Attorney General can cancel removal and adjust the status of an alien who is inadmissible or deportable if certain conditions are met, including being under 21 years old at the time of application. The CARE Act amends Section 240A of the Immigration and Nationality Act to allow for cancellation of removal and adjustment of status for certain aliens brought to the US as children. Conditions include being under 21 years old, having been physically present in the US for at least five years, demonstrating good moral character, and meeting educational requirements. The CARE Act amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to allow for cancellation of removal and adjustment of status for certain aliens brought to the US as children, under specific conditions. This includes meeting educational requirements and being considered for admission by a US institution of higher education. Restrictions apply to aliens who are inadmissible or deportable under certain sections of the law. The CARE Act allows for cancellation of removal and adjustment of status for certain aliens brought to the US as children, under specific conditions. Restrictions apply to aliens who are inadmissible or deportable under certain sections of the law. Attorney General determines extreme hardship to the alien, child, or parent, or inadmissibility or deportability under specific sections. The CARE Act allows for cancellation of removal and adjustment of status for certain aliens brought to the US as children. Aliens described in subsection (b)(5) must meet specific qualifications, including age requirements and timely application for relief. The CARE Act allows for cancellation of removal and adjustment of status for certain aliens brought to the US as children who meet specific qualifications, including age requirements and enrollment in a higher education institution. The confidentiality of information provided in the application under section 240A(b)(5) is protected by law. The CARE Act protects the confidentiality of information provided in applications under section 240A(b)(5) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Violations of this confidentiality can result in fines up to $10,000. Regulations regarding this protection must be proposed within 60 days. The Attorney General must publish proposed regulations within 60 days of the Act's enactment and final regulations within 120 days. These regulations will allow eligible individuals to apply for relief and will be subject to change after public comment. The Act allows eligible individuals to apply for relief under section 240A(b)(5) of the Immigration and Nationality Act without being placed in removal proceedings. It ensures that brief, casual, and innocent absences from the United States do not affect an alien's continuous physical presence. Additionally, a conforming amendment expands the eligibility criteria for relief under the Act. SEC. 5. ELIGIBILITY OF CANCELLATION APPLICANTS FOR EDUCATIONAL ASSISTANCE. Amends the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act to include aliens with pending relief applications under section 240A(b)(5) of the Immigration and Nationality Act as eligible for postsecondary educational assistance. Effective date is retroactive to August 22, 1996.
